image.altText: Anna Pak Poy smiles.

props.synopsis: Anna Pak Poy, who lost her son to an ultra-rare disease when he was 22 months old, says there should be more support from governments for people living with rare conditions.Â

title.children: About 2 million Australians live with a rare disease, often facing an isolating journey for answers

image.altText: A picture of two men is cropped into a bigger image of the front of a home with dozens of flowers laid out the front.

props.synopsis: NSW Police will continue investigating a property in Bungonia overnight where two bodies were found as a vigil is held for Sydney couple Jesse Baird and Luke Davies.

title.children: Tributes shared for Jesse Baird and Luke Davies as police continue investigating property where two bodies were found

image.altText: An army tank

props.synopsis: An Israeli company whose technology was stripped from Australian Army equipment over possible data security concerns three years ago has been awarded a fresh defence contract worth $917 million.

title.children: Controversial Israeli weapons company awarded $917 million Australian army contract

image.altText: A woman wearing a hijab and a man make a love heart with their hands.

props.synopsis: Maryam Sayed Deeb and Abdullah Abu Nahl got married during the Israel-Gaza war, but two days later they were killed in an Israeli air strike.

title.children: 'She did not have time to be happy': Maryam was killed days after marrying the love of her life

image.altText: A young woman with blonde hair sits at a computer desk, it is covered with stationary.

props.synopsis: It's official, men are paid more than women at many of the country's major companies, including banks, retailers, legal firms and mines, but what is being done to address it?

title.children: Workers reluctant to return to the office may intensify gender pay gap, lawyers warn

image.altText: A CFS firefighter stands next to a koala.

props.synopsis: Fire authorities have urged South Australians in seven districts to prepare for possible bushfires on Wednesday ahead of "extreme" conditions.Â

title.children: Aerial firefighting units on standby as South Australia prepares for 'extreme' fire danger

image.altText: Charred bushland following a fire

props.synopsis: Hot temperatures and strong winds are expected in Victoria and South Australia, with hundreds of firefighters deployed to contain potential outbreaks.Â Â

title.children: Victoria braces for another day of 'catastrophic' fire danger, a week on from bushfires that destroyed six homes

image.altText: Twisted metal transmission towers under a grey sky.

props.synopsis: The word "unprecedented" is losing impact as the world lurches from one crazy weather event to the next. The term "climate change" doesn't do enough to describe what is happening.

title.children: After a weird summer where floods gave way to heatwaves, scientists explain why we're seeing weather extremes 'on steroids'

image.altText: Four police officers stand under an awning attached to a police car, parked on a suburban street

props.synopsis: A 23-year-old man has died after allegedly being stabbed at his home in Adelaide's north this morning. Police say a 27-year-old man has been arrested and charged with murder.

title.children: Man charged with murder after young man dies from alleged stabbing in Adelaide's north

image.altText: An old black and white group photo with a man in glasses and a woollen jumper spotlighted in red.

props.synopsis: The Victorian Education Department sent unqualified teachers into classrooms in the 1960s and then failed to sack them following reports they were sexually abusing their students, according to recently discovered documents.

title.children: An educated man who preyed on his students': Woman sues Victorian government over alleged abuse by high school teacher

image.altText: Firefighters using foam to put out a car fire on a dead end street as a police office looks on

props.synopsis: A man has been charged with arson after a car was found destroyed at Kurralta Park in Adelaide's south-west on Monday. Officers are investigating whether the car is linked to a shooting at Wayville.Â

title.children: Police charge man with arson over car fire in Adelaide, investigating links to shooting

image.altText: Coles and Woolworths branding outside neighbouring supermarkets

props.synopsis: Accusations of price gouging have again been levelled at Coles after the supermarket giant revealed another bumper profit.

title.children: 'No-one has to earn a 30pc profit rate': Coles accused of gouging shoppers as they struggle to put food on table

image.altText: A tight shot of Jim Chalmers head, he wears a suit and red tie stands in front of a blue curtain

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers seeks to get ahead of the expected inflation jump in today's latest figures, warning the government knows the inflation fight is "not mission accomplished".

title.children: Government braces for inflation blip as wages fight looms

image.altText: A text message reading: 'Medicare: Due to the recent abnormal operation of your Medicare, we have to suspend your service.'

props.synopsis: Australian authorities say the newest scam threatens to suspend or freeze Medicare accounts.

title.children: Authorities say 'spike' in Medicare scam text messages

image.altText: A woman using a smartphone surrounded by beams of light

props.synopsis: The internet is filling up with machine-generated "zombie content" designed to game algorithms and scam humans. Experts call it the "great AI flood".

title.children: A 'great flood' of AI noise is coming for the internet and it's swallowing Twitter first

image.altText: Cattle graze under a tree at sunset

props.synopsis: Australia hopes China will soon drop tariffs on its wine, but the trade war continues to wreak havoc.

title.children: Trade war fallout continues as exporters hope for good news

image.altText: Graphic showing faces of five smiling teenage girls against green background covered with maths formulas.

props.synopsis: Maths anxiety usually starts in school but it can impact your career path, finances and confidence throughout life. The good news is most people can learn to love numbers.

title.children: Don't think you have a 'maths brain'? You might surprise yourself

image.altText: Female legal

props.synopsis: Three years after revelations of widespread sexual harassment and bullying rocked South Australia's legal profession, a review is underway to examine the effectiveness of the industry's response.

title.children: Sexual harassment complaints in legal profession at risk of hitting bureaucratic 'curtain', Chief Justice warns

image.altText: Smoke and an orange glow from a fire burning in the Cherry Gardens area of the Adelaide Hills.

props.synopsis: A formerÂ Country Fire Service volunteer who deliberately lit fires in the Adelaide Hills three years ago has been condemned in court by the agency's current chief, who said the firebug's actions put the communities at risk of an "Ash Wednesday-type" disaster and had tarnished the reputation of the entire CFS.

title.children: CFS chief blasts former volunteer over deliberately-lit Adelaide Hills bushfire

image.altText: A lady in a purple dress with a purple dress standing in front of a disabled park with her walking stick

props.synopsis: People living with disabilities in regional South Australia are moving to the state's capital due to a lack of accessible infrastructure and services.Â

title.children: Why people living with disabilities are considering moving away from regional areas

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt stands in front of an apartment building.

props.synopsis: Doing what we can to stop Australians being overcharged is important, not only for wage earners but also for businesses. And in the banking sector, there's a new idea for how we might do just thatÂ â and it's a beauty, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: A 'beauty' of an idea could help tackle the problem of price gouging in banking

image.altText: Band members wearing all black with faces covered by masks.

props.synopsis: Hitler salutes, white supremacy slogans and symbols of hate â¦ insiders say Nazi bands have become an open secret within Australia's metal scene, as fans prepare for the return of major international event Knotfest next month.

title.children: The underground Nazi world hiding in the metal music scene

image.altText: A female doctor wearing a stethoscope fills out a medical certificate

props.synopsis: Many workplaces require documentation for sick and carer's leave. With the rising costs of GPs, and cost-of-living pressures, this can be expensive, so, what options are available if you need a medical certificate?

title.children: What's the most cost-effective way of obtaining a medical certificate if you need one for work?

image.altText: A close up of a woman with green eyes smiling while wearing a blue cap and top.

props.synopsis: Prominent social media influencers are being recruited in a new effort to combat pro-vaping messaging online, to try to convince young Australians to give up the nicotine habit.

title.children: Sporting stars, comedians recruited in anti-vape campaign as vaping rules change again

image.altText: Prince William looking concerned

props.synopsis: Prince William has pulled out of attending a memorial service at Windsor Castle for his godfather, the late King Constantine of Greece, because of an unspecified personal matter, his office said.

title.children: Prince William pulls out of memorial service for late godfather, citing 'personal matter'

image.altText: A close portrait of a woman in business attire, who is looking at the camera with a neutral expression.

props.synopsis: NDIS Quality and Safeguards Commissioner Tracey Mackey announces she will "embark on new career opportunities" just two days before an independent report investigating a scandal exposed by Four Corners is due.

title.children: NDIS commissioner resigns days before report due into scandal exposed by Four Corners

image.altText: Scott Morrison gestures while standing in the House of Representatives

props.synopsis: Australia's 30th Prime Minister is finally about to leave the building, almost two years after losing the federal election.Â Defeated PMs tend not to hang around for this long, but asÂ a wise man once said, "It's not a race", writes Annabel Crabb.Â

title.children: Known for walking on both sides of the street, Morrison kept it up until the very end

image.altText: Albanese looks up while standing at a lectern, an Australian flag behind him.

props.synopsis: The government's overhaul of the stage 3 tax cuts passed the Senate unamended on Tuesday evening, having previously passed in the House of Representatives. The tax cuts will now become law.

title.children: Government's overhaul of stage 3 tax cuts pass Senate

image.altText: Former rugby league great Wally Lewis smiles for the cameras as he holds an orange t-shirt tagged "you only get one brain".

props.synopsis: Rugby league great Wally Lewis goes to Canberra to meet politicians, share his experiences of short-term memory loss and call for federal money to be put towards education and support for the fight against chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE).

title.children: 'My diary ... is my best friend': League great Wally Lewis urges politicians to put CTE funding in budget

image.altText: The rear of a plane with wheels down about to land on a runway

props.synopsis: As Tasmanians get ready to vote in a state election, experts are predicting a gloomy time ahead for the state, with a shrinking population and economic downturn expected.

title.children: People aren't moving to Tasmania any more, making for 'a very volatile situation'

image.altText: Two officers hold a banner saying Australian Federal Police in the Mardi Gras parade

props.synopsis: An AFP spokesperson says they will not march in the Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras this year, following the alleged murders of Jesse Baird and Luke Davies.

title.children: 'We understand their hurt': Australian Federal Police decide not to march at Mardi Gras

image.altText: Nurse standing outside.

props.synopsis: Rural hospitals across Australia are struggling to attract and retain nursing staff. An outback campus in Queensland is addressing the issue by training staff locally, but the union says more opportunities are needed.

title.children: Number of student nurses in outback region triples in three years as education shifts from bigger towns

image.altText: close up of a barista's hands making coffee into an aqua coloured mug

props.synopsis: Last year Labor passed legislation to criminalise wage theft, but its legislation did not fulfil part of its promise, according to experts.

title.children: Labor's promise to criminalise wage theft without overriding state laws is stalled. Here's why

image.altText: An explosion on a beach.

props.synopsis: The girl and her stepdad got quite a fright when they chanced across the explosive device, which was destroyed on the beach at Ulladulla.

title.children: Footage shows detonation of explosive device picked up by girl collecting shells before school

image.altText: A composite image of two people lying in hospital beds.

props.synopsis:
The number of Australians who received a kidney from a living donor was back to pre-COVID levels last year, helped along by a record year for a program that allows people to donate to strangers.
Â

title.children: Nico gave his kidney to a stranger to save his wife Belinda â and other anonymous donors are doing the same
